Ok, what I wanted to say is that why not having the physics bubble size stored in a variable that can be modified in game instead of a fixed size.

Is that possible?

> 
> Ok, what I wanted to say is that why not having the physics bubble size stored in a variable that can be modified in game instead of a fixed size.
> Is that possible?

I am just wondering do we must have only one physics bubble? We can't have more?

For example if I dropped first stage of rocket it should be in its own physics bubble, so I can make reusable stage like SpaceX Falcon.

While 2nd stage+payload would be in its own bubble burning to orbit.

Also making launch like Virgin Galactic would use this mechanic.
Interesting ! Can't wait for the Great Leap Forward in KSP !

> 
> I am just wondering do we must have only one physics bubble? We can't have more?
> For example if I dropped first stage of rocket it should be in its own physics bubble, so I can make reusable stage like SpaceX Falcon.
> 
> While 2nd stage+payload would be in its own bubble burning to orbit.
> 
> Also making launch like Virgin Galactic would use this mechanic.

I also was thinking it it is possible to have a system with multiple bubbles, that would be almost necessary for multiplayer also

> 
> Woah, hold your horses. The physics bubble goes 22.5 km in atmosphere now?
> Hopefully, it's been optimized significantly. The island runway is, what, 18km away? I've got so many crashed things over there... The lag would be bad. ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif)

> 
> And that is very bad for planetary bases, usually I was making base and landing site 3+ km away from that base to avoid lag during landing. Now I wouldn't be able to do that.
> IMO we need new option in command parts and that option would turn on/off that craft or base from physics bubble. No matter how close I am to my planetary base, even 2 meters shouldn't load it into bubble, only exception would be docking or claw. 
> 
> Of course things that are not in bubble can't be controlled, don't use power etc etc but I don't need those things for my planetary base, right? ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
> 
> And knowing few people in here I am sure, if you implement this one, you will get cities on Duna. 
> 
> Something that would need thousands of parts and would lag a lot with this feature wouldn't matter, we would be able to build one building next to other and turn it off from physics bubble and then build ten more buildings without the lag ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

I'll point you towards this section:

> 
> The Physics Bubble for vessels is no longer always set to 2.5km. **Those values are now defined separately for each possible situation**, so we now keep vessels in the atmosphere (or in sub-orbital trajectories) loaded up to 22.5km away..

"Landed", "in atmosphere" and "sub-orbital" are all separate situations. This means that you can keep the "landed" bubble range at 2.5km or even smaller so that you don't have slowdown issues with debris around KSC. Before this, mods could change the physics bubble size, but it was the same for all situations.

> 
> Great to hear the physics bubble has been extended, though I wish that we can toggle the distance to what we desire.

This!

Thank you for expanding the physics bubble, great news. But in the long run i think the player should be able to change the bubble even if that means the game performance decreases. A simple warning message like "this may cause performance issues" would be enough.

> 
> And that is very bad for planetary bases, usually I was making base and landing site 3+ km away from that base to avoid lag during landing. Now I wouldn't be able to do that.

Darn it. You're right. Now I don't want the 22.5km range. 

...but it sounded so good for air drops.

> 
> "Landed", "in atmosphere" and "sub-orbital" are all separate situations. This means that you can keep the "landed" bubble range at 2.5km or even smaller so that you don't have slowdown issues with debris around KSC. Before this, mods could change the physics bubble size, but it was the same for all situations.

...and questions answered later in the thread. Moving on.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-04-08T14:37:08Z" title="04/08/2015 02:37  PM" data-short="9 yr">April 8, 2015</time> by r\_rolo1**

Nice everything sounds good! I feel like based on these dev notes we're still at least a couple weeks away from release. That's not a bad thing by any means though. Keep up that polishing and bug squashing! (Also, I finish finals in three weeks, so if you want to release it after that I'd be okay with it).

> 
> Yes, but also even if you DID fire straight up to 10km and drop your boosters, there is NO WAY they'd get to the ground before you were 22.5km from that ground.
> tl;dr 22.5km is not as far as you think it is when you're going as fast as you do during typical first separation.

That's exactly why I'm still going to be developing StageRecovery and I hope SIT89 still develops FMRS. The expanded bubble will only be able to handle edge cases where you drop things fairly close to the ground and at low enough speeds, aka right after launch or from planes (the dropping things from planes will be IMMENSELY helpful). I'll probably add in some code to automatically deploy Stock parachutes on vessels that aren't the active one when they get within range of the ground to help reduce the amount of "My boosters exploded when they hit the ground without deployed parachutes!" reports, which are going to likely increase. If you have to deploy the chutes when you decouple, there's a good chance the boosters will never even get close to the ground before leaving the bubble, and there's a noticeable increase in the chance of them smacking into each other/the main rocket. RealChutes are smart enough that I probably won't add in any code for them.

I really hope the values are adjustable for each situation. I'd honestly like to reduce/keep the same bubble size in space and on the ground. With FMRS and StageRecovery I might even reduce it in atmosphere. But when playing with kOS I'd like to be able to make it pretty large in case I want to do things with multiple craft. The biggest benefit will be dropping things from planes though.

I'm looking forward to the balance changes to career mode. I like the idea of being able to see into the future of my science progress so I know what I'm working towards. My only concern is that, regardless of the amount of part-shuffling inside the nodes, is it still going to be possible to cap out the tech tree inside Kerbin's SOI? The biggest bummer about career gameplay to me is that the progression phase can be finished very fast unless you place arbitrary restrictions on yourself or push the science sliders super low.

> 
> Btw.... is there any news for the "deadly waters" on 1.0?

Not that I've heard. Which is really rather unfortunate.

Right now, water is a placeholder. It's a bit laggy, it's pretty dang ugly, and it's far deadlier than land... I really, really hope that SQUAD doesn't try to ship a "finished" game with water in its current state.

There are some other placeholders, too:

- Many parts' descriptions (especially the new wing bits) are a measly one sentence long, and contain very little information about the part. These should be expanded: it's easy to do so, and it would help new players and add a little more polish.
- The beautiful, cloudy sky that you can see when in the VAB and SPH is a pretty obvious mismatch with the 'real' cloudless sky on Kerbin. I would love SQUAD to either add clouds to Kerbin or remove them from the background of the VAB/SPH. (The latter would be easier, but the former would be very nice.)
- Also, it's always daytime in the VAB and SPH! I know it may be a little more difficult to realistically simulate lighting throughout the day and into the night, but it would add a nice touch.

Just little things like this (I could go on, but I don't have time to). I haven't heard anything about these little things yet, and you guys could probably do each of these in a day or less, with the possible exception of the water one. It would really add to the gameplay experience, show that y'all pay attention to detail, and make it clear that all placeholders in this game are gone. Just throwing this out there...

...oh, and because the above may have sounded a little critical and because I'm *trying* to be nicer, I would just like to say that the additions made this week sound great. Thanks for the wonderful devnotes SQUAD!

-Upsilon
